column1: '''The Tolkien Trust''' is a British charity founded in [[1977]] by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s children. As a charitable trust, it makes grants to a wide variety of organisations at the discretion of the current trustees.<ref>{{webcite
column5: website=[https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/charity-commission Charity Commission]}}</ref> It does not manage Tolkien's literary estate,<ref>{{webcite
column9: accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> even though its source of income is via the copyright it owns to some of Tolkien's works that were formerly owned by The [[Tolkien Estate]].

column1: Created on [[1 April]] [[1977]], and registered with the Charity Commission from [[2 June]] [[1977]], the Trust was founded by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s four children: [[John Tolkien
column5: Priscilla]]. Today, the trustees of the charity are Christopher, Priscilla, [[Michael George Tolkien]] (son of Michael, succeeding his sister Joan as a trustee in 2008),<ref name="Accounts2009"/> and Christopher's wife [[Baillie Tolkien]].<ref>{{webcite

column1: The Trust makes grants to other charitable causes at the discretion of the trustees. It currently does not accept unsolicited applications for funding,<ref>{{webcite

column1: From [[2003]] and [[2006]] the Trust and The [[Tolkien Estate]] demanded royalties from [[The Lord of the Rings (film series)
column5: articlename=My Father's "Eviscerated" Work - Son Of Hobbit Scribe J.R.R. Tolkien Finally Speaks Out
column8: accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> Following claims from [[New Line Cinema]] that the films failed to make a profit, on [[11 February]] [[2008]] The Tolkien Trust, The [[Tolkien Estate]] and [[HarperCollins]] filed a lawsuit seeking at least $150 million (7.5% of gross revenue) in damages. They accused New Line Cinema of "unabashed and insatiable greed" and the "infamous practice of creative 'Hollywood accounting'."<ref>{{webcite
column12: articlename=Tolkien heirs sue Lord of the Rings studio for $150m
column13: accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> The claim, which also attempted to stop production of the [[The Hobbit (film series)
column14: forthcoming ''Hobbit'' films]], was concluded on [[8 September]] [[2009]] with an out-of-court settlement.<ref>{{webcite
column17: articlename=Legal settlement clears way for 'Hobbit' movie
column20: accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> [[Christopher Tolkien]] said that they "regret that legal action was necessary, but are glad that this dispute has been settled on satisfactory terms"<ref>{{webcite
column24: articlename=New Line resolves lawsuit with Tolkien Trust and HarperCollins over 'Lord of the Rings'
column26: accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> and that "New Line may now proceed with its proposed films of 'The Hobbit'", whilst their lawyer said that they "feel vindicated and are entirely satisfied with the terms of the settlement." Alan Horn, president of [[Warner Bros.]] (owners of New Line Cinema) said "we all look forward to a mutually productive and beneficial relationship in the future".<ref>{{webcite
column29: articlename=Warner Bros. settles lawsuit over 'Lord of the Rings' licensing payments
column31: accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> Although both sides refused to reveal the size of settlement - simply saying that the Tolkien Trust would receive a "significant portion" - the Trust's accounts reveal that in [[2009]] and [[2010]] it received £24 million and £1.6 million respectively in film rights,<ref name="Accounts2009"/><ref name="Accounts2010"/> and in [[2011]] it received £603,515 in merchandising rights.<ref name="Accounts2011"/>

column1: On the [[19 November]] [[2012]], Priscilla Tolkien as a trustee of The Tolkien Trust, [[Tolkien Estate
column2: The Tolkien Estate]] and [[HarperCollins]] ("the plaintiffs") filed a lawsuit against [[Warner Bros.]], [[New Line Cinema]] and the [[Saul Zaentz Company]] ("the defendants") seeking damages of $80 million.<ref>{{webcite
column5: articlename=JRR Tolkien's daughter sues producers of The Hobbit
column8: accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> They claimed that Tolkien's copyright had been breached and that the defendants had no right to sell themed slot machines and downloadable video games; in the claim the plaintiffs state: "Not only does the production of gambling games patently exceed the scope of defendants' rights, but this infringing conduct has outraged Tolkien's devoted fan base, causing irreparable harm to Tolkien's legacy and reputation and the valuable goodwill generated by his works."<ref>{{webcite
column11: articlename=Trouble in the shire: Tolkien family sues movie makers for $80MILLION over 'Hobbit' trilogy merchandizing
column13: accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> They assert that the merchandising rights only extend to physical, and not electronic, products.<ref>{{webcite
column17: articlename=Gambling's a really bad hobbit: Tolkien family and Warner Bros at war over Lord of the Rings fruit machines
column19: accessed=7 July 2015}}</ref> On [[11 March]] [[2013]], Saul Zaentz and Warner Bros. filed counter-claims against the plaintiffs (including The Tolkien Trust) arguing that as a result of the Estate's actions the defendants had lost out on merchandising income, and that there has been a breach of good-faith by the Estate and the Trust.<ref>{{webcite
column23: articlename=Making Sense of the latest Tolkien Lawsuit

column1: The primary assets of The Tolkien Trust are the copyrights to certain works by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] which continue to provide income to the Trust. The assets held by The Tolkien Trust are a number of (many posthumous) publications by J.R.R. Tolkien:<ref name="Accounts2009"/>
* Renewal copyrights in ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' in the USA
* Author royalties from ''[[The Tolkien Family Album]]''
* 40% of the renewal copyrights in ''[[The Tolkien Reader]]'' in the USA
* "published editions of various philological writings and fragments"<ref name="Accounts2013"/>
The Trust also holds a number of sundry assets:
* Letters from Tolkien to A.B.M. Ronald and C. Martin (see "[[Letter to Amy Ronald (15 March 1969)]]" and "[[Letter to Amy Ronald (20 March 1969)]]")

* "Certain unpublished papers, letters, artistic works, pictures, photographs and other documents originally forming part of the Estate of J R R Tolkien, and the copyright in such materials formerly owned by the Estate."<ref name="Accounts2013"/>

The Trust does not partake in any fund-raising activity: all income received constitute royalties from copyrights and subsequent investments. Although the Trust holds literary assets no value is provided for them on the grounds that it would not be "practical and cost-effective"; as such, the primary assets of the Trust are cash and investments ([[wikipedia:Bond (finance)
column3: shares]]). The Trust has an [[wikipedia:Socially responsible investing
column4: ethical investment policy]] so has no investment in tobacco, or the manufacture of armaments.<ref name="Accounts2009"/> In [[2012]], gambling services was added to the list of investments the Trust would not hold.<ref name="Accounts2012"/>

column1: The Trust was founded on [[1 April]] [[1977]] and its financial year was the same as the [[wikipedia:Fiscal year#United_Kingdom
column2: United Kingdom's fiscal year]] for individuals ([[6 April]] - [[5 April]]). In [[2013]] the existed unincorporated charity was closed and its assets transferred to a new [[wikipedia:Charitable incorporated organisation
column3: charitable incorporated organisation]]; the new charity's financial year is the same as the calendar year.<ref name="Accounts2013"/>
